issues.text: Whether the present appeal is maintainable under Article 133(1)(c) of the Constitution notwithstanding the Code of Civil Procedure of the Jaipur State

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment and decree passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India that the present appeal has been preferred to this Court by leave of the Rajasthan High Court under article 133 1  c  of the Constitution. The learned counsel for the respondent raised a preliminary objection as to the maintainability of the appeal.

issues.text: Whether Mst. Laxmi acquired an absolute estate in the property under the oral will of Ramchandra or only a limited estate

arguments.claim: The appeal is not maintainable because under the Code of Civil Procedure of the Jaipur State, the decision of the Jaipur High Court was final and no appeal lay from it, and the review judgment modifying only improvements does not entitle reopening the 1949 decision.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this judgment and decree passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India that the present appeal has been preferred to this Court by leave of the Rajasthan High Court under article 133 1  c  of the Constitution. The learned counsel for the respondent raised a preliminary objection as to the maintainability of the appeal. He contended that according to the Code of Civil Procedure of the Jaipur State the decision of the Jaipur High Court had become final as no appeal lay from it and hence this appeal was incompetent.

arguments.court_reasoning: The operative decree is the 1950 review decree passed after Constitution; Art 133 applies; Jaipur CPC does not affect SC jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: The High Court erred in granting the certificate under Article 133.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel then contended that the High Court was in error in granting the certificate in this case. We are unable to agree. An inquiry was made into the valuation of the property and it was reported that its value was Rs. 20,000 or that the decision affected property of the value of above Rs. 20,000.

arguments.claim: The plaintiff's suit is barred by limitation as there was no evidence that the plaintiff locked the house after the tenant vacated on 24th August 1933, so possession discontinued then and suit filed after 12 years.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Bakshi Tek Chand for the appellant contended that the Courts below were in error in holding that the plaintiffs suit was within limitation. He urged that in order to bring the suit within limitation the plaintiff in paragraph 5 of the plaint alleged that after the death of Laxmi he kept tenants in the house, realised the rent and enjoyed it and that the last tenant vacated on the 24th August, 1933, and thereafter he went to his native place after locking the house, but that this allegation had not been made good by him, and as there was no evidence that he locked the house, it should be held that plaintiffs possession discontinued with effect from the 24th August, 1933, and hence his suit brought more than twelve years from that date was not within time.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t and the companytention is therefore negatived. Dr. Bakshi Tek Chand next companytended that Laxmi acquired an absolute title in the suit property un

arguments.court_reasoning: Presumption of continuity of possession until dispossession; all three lower courts unanimously found possession continued.

arguments.claim: Ramchandra intended to make a gift to Laxmi but could not perfect it due to deathbed; property devolved to widows by inheritance; Laxmi got only limited life estate under widows' gift, same as widows had.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the respondent on the other hand raised two contentions. He urged in the first instance that it seems that the intention of Ramchandra was to make a gift of the suit property in favour of Laxmi but he was unable to perfect the gift by executing a registered deed, being on his deathbed and in that situation the property devolved on his widow by inheritance and it only came to Laxmi under the widows gift and under it she could not get a larger interest than what the widow herself possessed, namely, a limited life estate, which terminated on her death.

arguments.court_reasoning: Oral will admitted by plaintiff; gift deed executed per will directions; widows had no title themselves.

arguments.claim: There is no evidence as to the terms of the oral will; hence presumption that gift/will to female heir confers only limited life interest.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, it was said that there was no evidence as to the terms of the oral will and that being so, the gift being in favour of a female heir, the presumption in the absence of evidence to the contrary was that the donee got only a limited life interest in the bequeathed property.

arguments.court_reasoning: Will admitted by plaintiff; gift deed recitals confirm will and absolute rights ('deal with any way you like'); intention to confer same title as testator.

arguments.claim: Laxmi acquired absolute title under her father's oral will; High Court erred in holding that express words are needed to confer absolute interest on female donee/heir.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Bakshi Tek Chand next contended that Laxmi acquired an absolute title in the suit property under the will of her father and that the High Court was in error in holding that unless there were express words indicating that the donor who had absolute interest in the gifted property intended to convey an absolute interest to her, the gift in favour of an heir who would ordinarily inherit a limited interest could not be construed as conferring an absolute interest.

arguments.court_reasoning: No presumption of limited estate for Hindu female; words of full ownership suffice; oral will + gift deed confer absolute; cites SC Ram Gopal, TPA s8, distinguishes old PC Shumsool.

arguments.claim: The operative decree is the 1950 review decree by Rajasthan HC post-Constitution, appealable under Art 133(1)(c); Jaipur CPC irrelevant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this objection is not well founded. The only operative decree in the suit which finally and conclusively determines the rights of the parties is the decree passed on the 5th of April, 1950, by the Rajasthan High Court and that having been passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India, the provisions of article 133 are attracted to it and it is appealable to this Court provided the requirements of that article are fulfilled.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff's possession continued after Laxmi's death till dispossessed; suit within 12-year limitation; presumption of continuity even without locking.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the Courts below that the plaintiff was in possession of this house even during the lifetime of Laxmi and continued in possession thereafter. Even if the tenant vacated the house on the 24th August, 1933, and the plaintiff did not lock it, his possession would be presumed to continue till he was dispossessed by some one. The law presumes in favour of continuity of possession.

arguments.claim: No presumption that grant/will to Hindu female confers only limited estate; absolute if words convey full ownership, same as for male; no express alienation power needed.
Mst. Laxmi became absolute owner; plaintiff has no title as Balabux is stridhan heir.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th of August, 1947, the suit was dismissed by the Civil Judge, who held that Mst. Laxmi became the absolute owner of the property, and the plaintiff therefore had no title to claim possession of it after her death, Balabux being her stridhan heir. The learned Judge however held that the suit was within limitation.

arguments.court_reasoning: SC restores trial court decree on merits; limitation agreed by all.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff continued in possession even during Laxmi's lifetime till dispossessed 5 Oct 1933; Laxmi had only limited estate under oral will/gift as no proof of absolute intent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that after the death of Laxmi the plaintiff continued in possession of the house till he was dispossessed by the defendant on the 5th of October, 1933, and that he was in possession even during her lifetime. On the main question in the case the High Court held that though the house was bequeathed to Laxmi by Ram chandra under an oral will, there was no proof that it conferred upon her an absolute interest in the property and that in the absence of any evidence indicating that the donor intended to convey an absolute interest to her, the gift being in favour of a female could only confer upon her a limited life estate.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reversed on both possession (though not contested further) and estate (no presumption limited; evidence shows absolute).

holdings.text: The appeal is maintainable under Article 133(1)(c) as the operative decree is the one passed on 5th April 1950 by Rajasthan High Court after the Constitution came into force, attracting Article 133; Jaipur State CPC does not affect Supreme Court jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this objection is not well founded. The only operative decree in the suit which finally and conclusively determines the rights of the parties is the decree passed on the 5th of April, 1950, by the Rajasthan High Court and that having been passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India, the provisions of article 133 are attracted to it and it is appealable to this Court provided the requirements of that article are fulfilled. The Code of Civil Procedure of the Jaipur State could not determine the jurisdiction of this Court and has no relevancy to the maintainability of the appeal. The requirements of article 133 having been fulfilled, this appeal is clearly competent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review decree of 1950 is final operative decree post-Constitution; Art 133 applies directly; state CPC cannot limit SC jurisdiction.

holdings.text: High Court justified in granting certificate under Article 133 as property value exceeded Rs 20,000 and substantial question of law involved.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree. An inquiry was made into the valuation of the property and it was reported that its value was Rs. 20,000 or that the decision affected property of the value of above Rs. 20,000. A substantial question of law was involved in the case, that is, whether a testamentary disposition by a Hindu in favour of a female heir conferred on her only a limited estate in the absence of evidence that he intended to confer on her an absolute interest in the property. In these circumstances the High Court was fully justified in granting the certificate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valuation threshold met; substantial law question on Hindu female estate; obiter SC would admit under Art 136.

holdings.text: Plaintiff's suit is within limitation as possession presumed continuous until dispossession, even without locking house; concurrent findings of lower courts upheld.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the Courts below that the plaintiff was in possession of this house even during the lifetime of Laxmi and continued in possession thereafter. Even if the tenant vacated the house on the 24th August, 1933, and the plaintiff did not lock it, his possession would be presumed to continue till he was dispossessed by some one. The law presumes in favour of continuity of possession. The three Courts below have unanimously held that on the evidence it was established that after the death of Laxmi plaintiff continued in possession of the house and the suit was within limitation. There are no valid grounds for reviewing this finding in the fourth Court and the contention is therefore negatived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of possession continuity; unanimous lower court findings on evidence; no grounds to interfere.

holdings.text: Ramchandra's oral will bequeathed absolute estate to Laxmi; gift deed executed by widows per will directions confirms absolute title ('deal with any way you like'); plaintiff not heir as property devolved to Laxmi's husband Balabux as stridhan heir.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff admitted oral will; gift deed recitals support full ownership intent; widows acted as per directions, no title themselves; same title as testator conferred.

holdings.text: No presumption of limited estate for Hindu female grantee; absolute estate if words convey full ownership, same as male; no express alienation power needed; old Privy Council view outdated per recent SC precedent.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows SC Ram Gopal; TPA s8 general principle applies equally; distinguishes old PC Shumsool; no Hindu law exception for females.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that this was the principle once deduced from the Privy Council decision in Mahomed Shumool V. Shewukram 1  wherein it was held that a bequest to a daughter-in-law passed a limited estate. The proposition laid down in Mahomed Shumsools case 1  was construed by the High Courts in India to mean that a gift of immovable property to a woman could not be deemed to confer upon her an absolute estate of inheritance which she could alienate at her pleasure unless the deed or will gave her in express terms a heritable estate or power of alienation.

precedents.cited_proposition: a bequest to a daughter-in-law passed a limited estate
precedents.cited_holding: a bequest to a daughter-in-law passed a limited estate

anchor.surface_text: The proposition laid down in Mahomed Shumsools case 1  was construed by the High Courts in India to mean that a gift of immovable property to a woman could not be deemed to confer upon her an absolute estate of inheritance which she could alienate at her pleasure unless the deed or will gave her in express terms a heritable estate or power of alienation. Later decisions of the Judicial Committee made it clear that if words were used  1  2 I.A. 7.

precedents.cited_proposition: a gift of immovable property to a woman could not be deemed to confer upon her an absolute estate unless express terms

anchor.surface_text: Shumsools case 1  has been examined in recent years in some High Courts and it has been observed that according to the law as understood at present there is numberpresumption one way or the other and there is numberdifference between the case of a male and the case of a female, and the fact that the donee is a woman does number make the gift any the less absolute where the words would be sufficient to companyvey an absolute estate to a male  see Nagammal v. Subbalakshmi Ammal 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: no presumption one way or the other regarding absolute estate for female donee; no difference between male and female donee

anchor.surface_text: The matter has number been set at rest by the decision of this Court in Ram Gopal Nand Lal 3 . In this case it was observed as follows-- It may be taken to be quite settled that there is numberwarrant for the proposition of law that when a grant of an immovable property is made to a Hindu female, she does number get an absolute or alienable interest in such property, unless such power is expressly companyferred upon her.

precedents.cited_proposition: no warrant for proposition that grant to Hindu female does not confer absolute or alienable interest unless expressly conferred
precedents.cited_holding: there is no warrant for the proposition of law that when a grant of an immovable property is made to a Hindu female, she does not get an absolute or alienable interest unless expressly conferred

precedents.citation: Mst. Kollani Kuar v. Luchmi Kuar 4

anchor.surface_text: The reasoning adopted by Mitter J. of the Calcutta High Court in Mst. Kollani Kuar v. Luchmi Kuar 4 , which was approved of and accepted by the Judicial Committee in a number of decisions, seems to me to be unassailable.

precedents.case_name: Mst. Kollani Kuar v. Luchmi Kuar
precedents.cited_proposition: reasoning that there is no presumption of limited estate for Hindu female grantee

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the Privy Council as early as in the case of Tagore V. Tagire  5  that if an estate were given to a man without express words of inheritance, it would, in the absence of a companyflicting companytext, carry, by Hindu Law, an estate of inheritance. This is the general principle of law which is recognized and embodied in section 8 of the Transfer of Property Act

precedents.cited_proposition: estate given to a man without express words of inheritance carries estate of inheritance by Hindu Law
precedents.cited_holding: if an estate were given to a man without express words of inheritance, it would [...] carry [...] an estate of inheritance

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this objection is not well founded. The only operative decree in the suit which finally and conclusively determines the rights of the parties is the decree passed on the 5th of April, 1950, by the Rajasthan High Court and that having been passed after the coming into force of the Constitution of India, the provisions of article 133 are attracted to it and it is appealable to this Court provided the requirements of that article are fulfilled. The Code of Civil Procedure of the Jaipur State could not determine the jurisdiction of this Court and has no relevancy to the maintainability of the appeal. The requirements of article 133 having been fulfilled, this appeal is clearly competent.
For the reasons given above we allow the appeal, set aside the decree of the High Court decreeing the plaintiffs suit and restore the decree of the trial Court dismissing the plaintiffs suit.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree. An inquiry was made into the valuation of the property and it was reported that its value was Rs. 20,000 or that the decision affected property of the value of above Rs. 20,000. A substantial question of law was involved in the case, that is, whether a testamentary disposition by a Hindu in favour of a female heir conferred on her only a limited estate in the absence of evidence that he intended to confer on her an absolute interest in the property. In these circumstances the High Court was fully justified in granting the certificate.
For the reasons given above we allow the appeal, set aside the decree of the High Court decreeing the plaintiffs suit and restore the decree of the trial Court dismissing the plaintiffs suit.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the Courts below that the plaintiff was in possession of this house even during the lifetime of Laxmi and continued in possession thereafter. Even if the tenant vacated the house on the 24th August, 1933, and the plaintiff did not lock it, his possession would be presumed to continue till he was dispossessed by some one. The law presumes in favour of continuity of possession. The three Courts below have unanimously held that on the evidence it was established that after the death of Laxmi plaintiff continued in possession of the house and the suit was within limitation. There are no valid grounds for reviewing this finding in the fourth Court and the contention is therefore negatived.
For the reasons given above we allow the appeal, set aside the decree of the High Court decreeing the plaintiffs suit and restore the decree of the trial Court dismissing the plaintiffs suit.
